content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-076-03-A |Item_parent=Alcohol dependence |Item_parent_short=Alcohol dependence |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the comparative elements of dependence (ICD 11) and alcohol use disorder (DSM5) |Description=Dependence (ICD 11) corresponds to moderate to severe alcohol use disorders (DSM5). |Rubric=Definition |Contributors= |Order=3}} DSM-5 defines "alcohol use disorder" as mild, moderate or severe, using the same criteria as the ICD. Dependence (ICD) corresponds to moderate and severe "alcohol use disorder" (DSM-5).

properties.question: In the context of diagnostic criteria for alcohol-related disorders, how does the ICD-11's definition of dependence compare to that of DSM-5's alcohol use disorder?
properties.option_a: ICD-11 considers dependence as a milder form than DSM-5's alcohol use disorder.
properties.option_b: ICD-11 and DSM-5 both categorize dependence as a spectrum, with ICD-11 specifically defining moderate and severe alcohol use disorders.
properties.option_c: DSM-5's alcohol use disorder includes dependence, but ICD-11 does not recognize dependence at all.
properties.option_d: ICD-11 categorizes dependence as a separate condition, not related to DSM-5's alcohol use disorder.
